review.title: Towards balanced clustering - part 1 (preliminaries)
review.abstract: The article contains a preliminary glance at balanced clustering problems. Basic balanced structures and combinatorial balanced problems are briefly described. A special attention is targeted to various balance/unbalance indices (including some new versions of the indices): by cluster cardinality, by cluster weights, by inter-cluster edge/arc weights, by cluster element structure (for element multi-type clustering). Further, versions of optimization clustering problems are suggested (including multicriteria problem formulations). Illustrative numerical examples describe calculation of balance indices and element multi-type balance clustering problems (including example for design of student teams).

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 6.03 065v 1 [cs.D S] 9 Jun 201 7 Towards balanced clustering - part 1 (preliminaries) Mark Sh. Levin * The article provides a preliminary look at balanced cluster problems. Basic balanced structures and combinatorial balanced problems are briefly described, with particular attention given to various equilibrium / imbalance indices (including some new versions of the indices): cluster cardinality, cluster weights, edge / arc weights between clusters, cluster element structure (for element multi-type clustering), and suggested versions of optimization problems (including multi-criterion problem formulations). Illustrative numerical examples describe the calculation of balance indices and element multi-type balance cluster problems (including an example for designing student teams).Keywords: balanced cluster formation, combinatorial possibilities, hay binations.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Balancing processes play a central role in many theoretical and practical areas. (Fig. 1) [9,10,12,31,35, 36,40,56,61,93,110,120,129,139,150] The corresponding balancing problems are balanced problems in various technical areas, for example: manufacturing systems, computing systems, electricity / electricity systems, radio technology systems, communication systems and civil planning systems. Similar balancing problems are investigated in technical management (e.g. coordination science), communication (e.g. synchronization as time-based balancing), organizational science, psychology. In recent decades, the balancing approaches are very important from the point of view of system modularity.

sections.text: The balanced cluster problem is therefore aimed at finding the cluster solution with minimum equilibrium index (e.g. index above). sections.heading: 6.1. Illustration example for description of cluster structure
sections.text: Table 4 contains a description of cluster structures and corresponding multiset estimates, e.g. from Figure 4 (seven clusters, tree types and additional "empty" element type).Table 5 contains the simplified proximity (or distance) between the multiset estimates of the clusters: δ (e (Xι1), e (Xι2), ι1, ι2 (1,..., 7).The following balance sheet indices result: B-c (X) = | X6 | − | X1 | = 2, B-s (X) = δ (e (X6), e (X1) = δ (((2, 1, 4, 0), (1, 1, 3, 2) = 4.

sections.heading: 6.2. Network-like illustration example
sections.text: In general, a wireless sensor network (WSN) can be considered as a multi-layer system (Fig. 15): (1) sensors, (2) clusters, (3) cluster heads, (4) database servers, (5) decision / control center. (6) The design process of the architecture is based on (1) element type clusters (i.e., sensor / end nodes, cluster heads, etc.).11Here, a numerical example from Fig. 10 is considered (three types of elements: common nodes, nodes for relays, cluster heads): A = 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 9, 10, 13, 14, 15}. The parameters of the elements and their linkages are presented in Table 6 (element types, element types) and Table 7 (weights of edges, symmetric relationship).

sections.heading: 6.3. Cluster structure based balanced clustering for student teams
7. Conclusion
sections.text: The paper describes the preliminary outline of various combinatorial compensation problems, including new balance indices for cluster solutions, multi-criterion combinatorial models and examples. It may be useful to identify some future research directions: (1) special investigation of balance indices for balanced structures (degree of balance, etc.); (2) investigation of various compensation problems in combinatorial optimization (e.g. balanced tornister-like problems, balanced allocation problems, balanced waste packaging problems); (3) consideration of uncertainty in the compensation models; (4) investigation of compensation problems in networking (e.g. design of multi-layer communication networks, routing); (5) investigation of augmentation approaches for compensation structures taking into account the improvement of structure balance; and (6) use of the described approaches in CS / Engineering education.

sections.heading: 8. Acknowledgments
sections.text: The research was carried out at the Institute of Information Transmission Problems of the Russian Academy of Sciences and supported by the Russian Science Foundation (Funding 14-50-00150, "Digital Technologies and their Applications").

metadata.abstractText: The article contains a preliminary glance at balanced clustering problems. Basic balanced structures and combinatorial balanced problems are briefly described. A special attention is targeted to various balance/unbalance indices (including some new versions of the indices): by cluster cardinality, by cluster weights, by inter-cluster edge/arc weights, by cluster element structure (for element multi-type clustering). Further, versions of optimization clustering problems are suggested (including multicriteria problem formulations). Illustrative numerical examples describe calculation of balance indices and element multitype balance clustering problems (including example for design of student teams).
